title: Stored XSS in SVG file as data: url

profile.name: Shopify
profile.about: Shopify is a multi-channel commerce platform that helps people sell online, in-store, and everywhere in between.

vulnerability_information: Hi Shopify team, In rich text editors (products, gifts, pages, etc) you allow *data:* URLs to be set as image sources, and I was able to store XSS in such image. While won't execute script that is stored inside the SVG it points to, if one opens the image, the script will be executed. What is important here is that you actually can use javascript here to access /admin area. #Steps to reproduce: 1. Create a product with such html description: ```html ``` Inside this base 64 is code like this: ```html ``` In this example i request my shop's admin page and in the video it looks like CORS is okay with it. 2. Open the resulting image in new tab and observe script execution in console. #POC video: █████ ## Impact With little user interaction we can execute arbitrary scripts in victim's account.

activities.message:
The behaviour observed is similar to what I've seen before in timeline comments. If you will attach SVG file to timeline, it will be displayed as background-image before you post comment. Presumably, after you post comment, svg will be uploaded to your cdn, but before that it is stored as blob. But at that point it is only self-xss since you nobody will be able to open the link and see the SVG, when in this report SVG is stored for everybody to see
{F1388053}

Hi,
Could you please take a look at this issue and tell me it is not another duplicate?😅 Thanks

Hi @irisrumtub! 
We are still looking into this one, apologies for the delay. We should have an update for you tomorrow!

Hi Jenn,
thank you for quick response. I revisited my writing and wanted to make some things clear:
1. POC video demonstrates XSS firing on two different accounts, so everyone who has access to any rich text editor will be able to plant XSS / be subject to the attack.
2. Regarding my first comment - SVG that you attach to timeline comment can have 2 states: a) until you publish your comment, it is stored in your temporary s3 bucket; b) when you publish your comment, it is stored on cdn.shopify.com. You can only fire self-XSS when svg is in state a and you manually access its blob:https:// url (which is only availible to you if you post it), but not in state b since the content disposition is set to download.

Hi @irisrumtub,

Thanks for your report. We have validated your findings and our engineering team is working on a fix. We will be in touch soon regarding bounty eligibility!

Hi, are those your IPs? Because my shop gets visited by those daily:
█████████
████
█████

Hi @irisrumtub,

Thanks again for your report!

We're awarding a $2,900 bounty for this issue. We've assigned user interaction required in this case as in order for the payload to trigger, the victim needs to click on the image being previewed. The execution of arbitrary javascript would result in Confidentiality and Integrity impact but only for the shop in question.

Please find below our rationale generated using our [CVSS calculator](https://shopify.github.io/appsec/cvss_calculator/).

```
# Base Score CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:R/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:N 4.6
# Environment: Core

### Attack Complexity: L
* Specific conditions or measurable effort to exploit?: No

### Privileges Required: L
* Requires privileged account (not self-registered)?: Yes
* Does the attacker need extensive permissions?: No

### User Interaction: R
* Requires victim to perform some action during exploit?: Yes

### Scope: U
* Can the attacker impact a separate service?: No

### Confidentiality: L
* How much data could be accessed?: Most or All
* How much of Shopify is impacted?: Some

### Integrity: L
* How much data could be changed?: Most or All
* How much of Shopify is impacted?: Some

### Availability: N
* Level of disruption to network service?: None
```

Hi! Thanks for the amazing bounty!
But just for the sake of knowledge how is this one different from #1147433 if you could explain?

You set priveleges required to none there 
"We have set Privileges Required to None in this case, as the most likely attack scenario is a merchant pasting a malicious product description"

Do you think this case is different? Since it's basically the same injection place: rich text editor (products and so on). If so, could you explain the reasoning?

Thank you

Hi @irisrumtub,

I will review this with the team, and get back to you about your inquiry.

Hi @iristumtub,
Thank you for following up, and our apologies for the delayed response. We have reviewed the CVSS score for this report, and agree that Privileges Required should have been None in this case (as the most likely attack scenario is a merchant unknowingly uploading a malicious SVG). This brings the CVSS score to `CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:N` (5.4). For this reason we are an **awarding an additional $2,400 on this report**, bringing the total bounty to $5,300 for CVSS 5.4.
Thank you oh so much. I will be back with New stuff soon

LGTM. The file is not stored as blob anymore, but as data: url instead, and even if you open the file the javascript will not execute in modern browsers due to security limitations. I checked:
* rich text in products/gift products
* policies

and since there were no blobs anymore it's safe to say it's fixed

{F2079535}
It amazes me how seriously you guys take your security.

Thanks for the confirmation, @irisrumtub!

It's also always great to hear feedback like this :) 
>It amazes me how seriously you guys take your security.

additional_data.new_title: Stored XSS in SVG file as data: url

summaries.content:
On July 24, 2021, @irisrumtub discovered it was possible to insert an XSS payload encoded in an SVG file by using `data:` url's in the admin's rich text editor.
Our engineers deployed a fix that avoid converting the `data:` URL into a `blob:` URL, which impedes the exploitation of this vulnerability.
